question: What are the three main responsibilities of Canadian citizens?
options: Obey the law, serve on a jury, vote in elections
Pay taxes, own property, speak English or French
Serve in the military, volunteer, respect the flag
Travel across Canada, work, support the economy
explanation: Canadian citizens must obey the law, serve on a jury when called, and vote in elections.

question: Which of the following is a legal right protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
options: The right to free healthcare
The right to vote in federal and provincial elections
The right to own property
The right to receive government employment
explanation: The Charter guarantees the right to vote in federal and provincial elections.

question: What is one of the fundamental freedoms protected by the Charter?
options: Freedom to receive free housing
Freedom of conscience and religion
Freedom to avoid jury duty
Freedom to travel without identification
explanation: The Charter protects freedom of conscience and religion as a fundamental freedom.

question: Which of the following is a responsibility of Canadian citizens?
options: To learn both official languages
To respect the rights and freedoms of others
To serve in the military
To donate to charity
explanation: Citizens must respect the rights and freedoms of others as part of Canadian democratic values.

question: What does the Charter protect regarding mobility rights?
options: The right to travel only within your province
The right to move and live anywhere in Canada
The right to travel without a passport
The right to free public transportation
explanation: Mobility rights allow citizens to move and live anywhere in Canada.

question: Which of the following is a democratic right of Canadian citizens?
options: The right to run for political office
The right to free university education
The right to own a business
The right to receive government benefits
explanation: Citizens have the democratic right to run for political office.

question: What is the significance of the rule of law in Canada?
options: Only elected officials must follow the law
Everyone, including government, must follow the law
Laws apply only to citizens
Laws can be ignored if they seem unfair
explanation: The rule of law means everyone, including government officials, must follow the law.

question: Which of the following is a responsibility shared by all Canadians?
options: To speak both official languages
To help others in the community
To obey the law
To serve in the armed forces
explanation: Obeying the law is a responsibility shared by all Canadians.

question: What does equality under the law mean in Canada?
options: Everyone is treated the same regardless of race, gender, or background
Everyone must earn the same income
Everyone must speak the same language
Everyone must vote for the same political party
explanation: Equality under the law means all individuals are treated equally regardless of personal characteristics.

question: Which of the following is a right of Canadian citizens but not permanent residents?
options: The right to live and work anywhere in Canada
The right to vote in federal elections
The right to receive healthcare
The right to be protected by the Charter
explanation: Only Canadian citizens can vote in federal elections.
